blimpcontrol.motor

Motor module for the blimpcontrol library.

class blimpcontrol.motor.Motor(pin1: int, pin2: int, pwm_pin: int | None = None)

Bases: object

A class to represent a bidirectional brushed DC motor controlled by a DRV8871-like driver.

The DRV8871 typically uses two pins for direction and PWM for speed. This class simplifies it to two pins for direction and assumes speed is managed by PWM on one of these pins or a separate enable pin if the driver supports it. For this example, we’ll treat pin1 and pin2 as controlling direction, and speed will be an abstract concept passed to a PWM controller (simulated).

Parameters:

  • pin1 (int) – The first GPIO pin connected to the motor driver.

  • pin2 (int) – The second GPIO pin connected to the motor driver.

  • pwm_pin (int, optional) – Optional PWM pin if speed control is separate. For DRV8871, often one of the direction pins is PWM’d.

VALID_RAMPS = ['linear', 'quadratic', 'log', 'bezier']
spin_forward(speed: int, ramp: str = 'linear') → None

Spin the motor forward.

Parameters:

  • speed (int) – The motor speed (0-255).

  • ramp (str, optional) – The ramp profile. Defaults to “linear”.

Raises:

ValueError – if speed or ramp is invalid.

Example:

motor.spin_forward(150, ramp="quadratic")

spin_reverse(speed: int, ramp: str = 'linear') → None

Spin the motor reverse.

Parameters:

  • speed (int) – The motor speed (0-255).

  • ramp (str, optional) – The ramp profile. Defaults to “linear”.

Raises:

ValueError – if speed or ramp is invalid.

Example:

motor.spin_reverse(100)

stop() → None

Stop the motor (brake).

This typically involves setting both control pins to LOW or both to HIGH for a DRV8871 driver to brake the motor. :example: motor.stop()

cleanup()

Clean up GPIO resources. Call this when the motor is no longer needed.
